reviews.review_text: Interesting novel set in the tulip crazed Holland of the 17th century.  The best part of the book for me, frankly, was the setting.  Holland was at a truly pivotal moment in its development largely thanks to the development of a substantial middle class with money to invest in art (think Rembrandt, Hals, Vermeer, etc), and tulip futures!If you like a novelization of the period, and particularly the tulip craze, you may also like Gregory Maguire's (yes, the author of Wicked!) Confessions of an Ugly Stepsister. If you want to learn more about how Holland wound up bound to this flower, I also  enjoyed the book Tulipmania.

Fiction always disappoints me, because it is too simple: too few characters, too little complex dialogue, unreal situations.  I enjoyed the history that was the background for this book, but not the main story line as much.  Oh, well...
What an epic story told with an artistic almost poetic rhythm. A classic love affair but so many whimsical twists. I thoroughly loved it!
Book was well written but I expected to learn more about the Tulip-mania in Amsterdam at the time, not elicit affairs and schemes that had very little to do with Tulips.
This book was a little far-fetched. I found it rather tedious with nothing to make me wish to read anything further by this writer.
Karma is just. That’s all I have to say that describes this book to a capital T!! Such a great book!

I thought it was good since I  am a horticulturist and have known about this from history.  But I think that the book  should have focused more on the tulip bulb industry and breeding and production which makes a certain bulb species so valuable.  Even today there are different grades and prices for specific species. The cheapest that are sold are referred to as "the floor sweepings", meaning all the leftovers. There is now tight security involving shipments from Holland which land on the New York docks.Before  when the shipments arrived the most valuable species no longer arrived although they had been loaded and sent. Also the containers were left on the hot docks and not given priority to be dispersed so heat sensitive monitors are in the containers and blame for mishandling can be determined for insurance claims.

summary:
n 1630s Amsterdam, tulipomania has seized the populace. Everywhere men are seduced by the fantastic exotic flower. But for wealthy merchant Cornelis Sandvoort, it is his young and beautiful wife, Sophia, who stirs his soul. She is the prize he desires, the woman he hopes will bring him the joy that not even his considerable fortune can buy.

Cornelis yearns for an heir, but so far he and Sophia have failed to produce one. In a bid for immortality, he commissions a portrait of them both by the talented young painter Jan van Loos. But as Van Loos begins to capture Sophia's likeness on canvas, a slow passion begins to burn between the beautiful young wife and the talented artist.

As the portrait unfolds, so a slow dance is begun among the household’s inhabitants. Ambitions, desires, and dreams breed a grand deception—and as the lies multiply, events move toward a thrilling and tragic climax.

In this richly imagined international bestseller, Deborah Moggach has created the rarest of novels—a lush, lyrical work of fiction that is also compulsively readable. Seldom has a novel so vividly evoked a time, a place, and a passion.

“Sumptuous prose . . . reads like a thriller.” The New York Times Book Review
